I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  The  proposed  knowledge  and  support  technical  assistance  (TA)  aims  to  provide 
institutional support to the National Payments Corporation of India (NPCI) and its wholly owned 
international subsidiary-NPCI International Payments Limited (NIPL) in accelerating adoption of 
digital payments and promoting financial technology (fintech)1 cooperation across Asia. 
 
2.  The TA is consistent with Asian Development Bank (ADB) Strategy 2030 Operational 
Priority 1: Addressing Remaining Poverty and Reducing Inequalities by supporting NPCI in 
enhancing financial inclusion through seamless digitization of payments; Operational Priority 2: 
Gender Equality and Women’s Empowerment; Operational Priority 6: Strengthening Governance 
and  Institutional  Capacity;  and  Operational  Priority  7:  Fostering  Regional  Cooperation  and 
Integration (RCI) by supporting NPCI/NIPL in promoting financial cooperation across the region.2 
The TA is aligned with the country partnership strategy (CPS) for India, 2018–2022 by providing 
inclusive  financial  infrastructure  and  services  and  promoting  regional  cooperation  and 
integration.3 The TA is also supportive of the Digital India Programme,4 a flagship financial 
inclusion program of the government that aims to make digital payments accessible to all 
segments of the population in a convenient, easy, affordable, quick and secured manner.5 
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
3.  The traditionally cash-driven Indian economy has responded well to the fintech opportunity, 
primarily triggered by a surge in e-commerce and smartphone proliferation. The transaction value 
for the Indian fintech sector is estimated to be $33 billion in 2016 and is forecasted to reach $73 
billion in 2020 growing at a 5-year compounded annual growth rate (CAGR) of 22%.6 The number 
of fintech startups in India has grown from 730 in 2015 to 2,000 in 2019.7 Likewise, India’s digital 
payments subsector has seen maximum fintech activity with 375 startups, with transactions 
growing at a CAGR of 34% over the same period.8 Subsequently, there is a consistent increase 
in digital payments transaction turnover in relation to gross domestic product (GDP) (at current 
prices), from 7.14% in fiscal year (FY) 2016, 7.85% in FY2017 and 8.42% in FY2018.  
 
4.  This steep growth was made possible by the proactive initiatives of the government in 
promoting fintech. The government’s push toward a digitized economy with demonetization, 
introduction  of  fintech  initiatives  such  as  the  Unified  Payments  Interface  (UPI),9 and  the 
connection of financial services such as bank accounts to Aadhaar10 have led to a spurt in the 
growth of fintech. 
 
1  Fintech is an industry comprising companies that seek to improve and automate the delivery and use of financial 
services. At its core, fintech is utilized to help users manage their financial operations, processes, and lives by utilizing 
specialized software and algorithms that are used on computers and, increasingly, smartphones.

2 
5.  To further promote fintech-enabled digital payments services, the government established 
NPCI,11 an umbrella organization created by the Reserve Bank of India (RBI) and the Indian 
Banking Association with the core objective of promoting a cashless digital economy, enabling 
payments systems that are secure, efficient, fast and affordable. It is focused on providing 
infrastructure and bringing innovations in the retail payments and settlement systems by using 
technology to achieve greater reach and efficiency in operations. Further, RBI recently released 
the  Payments  and  Settlements  System  in  India:  Vision  2019–2021,12 which  makes  digital 
payments a key focus area and puts emphasis on the role of the payment ecosystem13 and 
infrastructure in driving safer, convenient and faster payments. 
 
6.  NPCI now further intends to boost fintech and digital payments transactions internationally 
especially in the Asia and the Pacific region. It is estimated that $1.7 billion is transacted between 
India and its neighboring countries through tourism and remittances alone.14 Even on the fintech 
application development, several discrete innovations have taken place in different countries 
across the region. These local evolutions have reshaped payment processes and changed the 
domestic retail payments landscape in the local markets by lowering transaction costs. The onset 
of  COVID-19  pandemic  has  revealed  an  even  greater  role  for  cashless  digital  mode  of 
transactions. This is likely to prompt a much higher demand for fintech-based digital payment 
applications across the region over the next couple of years.  
 
7.  While the government has promoted an enabling climate for the fintech industry including 
deepening international transactions, a dynamic policy and regulatory architecture will need to 
match the speed of innovations in this sector. Upgrading the existing institutional expertise is 
pivotal to NPCI and NIPL for not only ensuring compliance with evolving domestic regulations15 
but also for advancing its international engagements with other nodal fintech agencies operating 
in other countries across Asia and the Pacific. At the cross-border front, a coordinated approach 
by nodal agencies within countries on the technical, legal and regulatory aspects is needed to 
expand the scale of operations and lower transactions costs for fintech firms at the international 
level. Given that NPCI/NIPL would need to advance its existing understanding of the policy and 
regulatory frameworks in the partner countries and keep up with the evolving fintech innovations 
in  the  region,  a  collaborative  approach  through  institutional  strengthening  frameworks  is 
imperative to build a mutually beneficial and efficient regional fintech ecosystem that enhances 
digital development across the region.  
 
8.  The local development of fintech industries and digital payments markets, and regional 
cooperation particularly in South and Southeast Asia can benefit from the experiences of other 
regional markets. Countries like the Republic of Korea with high mobile network penetration and 
usage have been successful in registering steep fintech growth within a short period of time. The 
Korean government has launched a series of initiatives including a $252 million startup fund

3 
dedicated  to  fintech,  creation  of  regulatory  fintech  sandbox,16 and  the  launch  of  fintech 
accelerators that can have a tremendous impact if replicated in other countries. The Financial 
Services  Commission  (FSC)  of the  Republic  of  Korea  has  also  taken  up  key  policy  level 
interventions as stipulated in Measures to Promote Fintech Scale-ups.17 The policy aims to 
provide fintech firms with overseas business opportunities and to strengthen inter-governmental 
cooperation including the launch of fintech labs across ASEAN countries.   
 
9.  This TA will address the capacity building needs of NPCI and NIPL by providing advanced 
institutional support based on regional collaboration. NPCI and NIPL need to constantly advance 
technical, legal and regulatory institutional capacity to effectively respond to the rapidly evolving 
digital market needs both within the country and across the region. An effective strategy to 
address capacity advancement needs in an ever-changing fintech landscape is to build robust 
partnerships with other regional nodal agencies, which collectively can address the fintech 
challenges by learning and leveraging from each other’s experience. Through international 
partnerships, the TA intends to expand the adoption of cross-border digital payments between 
India and other countries across Asia and the Pacific region. 
 
10.  The TA aims to support NPCI and NIPL in undertaking operationally relevant analytical 
studies  on  the  key  issues  and  challenges  surrounding  fintech  development,  and  on  the 
requirements of identified potential regional partners in promoting interregional cashless digital 
transactions, using primary and secondary digital payments market research and analysis, and 
expert  stakeholder  consultations,  among  others.  The  TA  will  further  provide  institutional 
advancement support to NPCI and NIPL, incorporating learnings from the experiences of the 
industry in the Republic of Korea, and will help NIPL establish partnerships on digital payments 
solutions with nodal agencies in other countries across Asia and the Pacific region. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
11.  The TA is aligned with the following impact: seamless digitization of payments accelerated 
(footnote 4). The TA will have the following outcome: regional partnerships and collaborations 
that facilitate adoption of fintech-based digital payments systems established. 
 
B.  Outputs, Methods, and Activities 
 
12.  The TA has two major outputs:  
 
13.  Output 1: Fintech market development plans for promoting cross-border digital 
payments by National Payments Corporation of India and NPCI International Payments 
Limited developed. This output aims to promote cashless transactions and fintech proliferation 
between India and other countries across Asia and the Pacific region. Each fintech market 
development plan will involve crafting a differentiated country strategy in terms of systems, 
marketing and public outreach, and infrastructure and enabling regulatory framework that meet 
the needs of fintech industries in India and the respective partner countries in the region. The 
plans will be based on the analyses of local markets, digital payments landscape, associated risks, 
legal compliances, and expected cost and revenue. The plans will help provide insights on issues 
such as business scope, status of ongoing partnerships, acceptance statistics, development cost, 
 
16 Sandbox: a virtual space in which new or untested software or coding can be run securely. 
17 FSC. 2019. Measures to Promote Fintech Scale-Ups.

4 
and various marketing cost involved in the process. The fintech market development plans will be 
guided by exploring global best practices to arrive at innovative and customized solutions. The 
TA will also support NPCI/NIPL in establishing partnerships with nodal agencies in selected 
countries,  which  together  can  effectively  capitalize  on  the  efficiencies  involved  in  a  digital 
economy.18  
 
14.  Output 2: Institutional capacity of National Payments Corporation of India and NPCI 
International Payments Limited advanced. This TA will further advance NPCI and NIPL 
capacity and systems in terms of information technology, regulatory and legal compliances, and 
big-data management that are pivotal in ensuring efficient and effective delivery of flagship 
government initiatives like Pradhan Mantri Jan Dhan Yojna (PMJDY),19 FASTag,20 and Direct 
Benefit Transfer Scheme, and to rapidly reach out to urban and rural market segments in retail 
and small business sectors across India. Fulfillment of this output will be assisted by NPCI’s 
partnership with Korean fintech companies backed by the Republic of Korea’s FSC and technical 
collaboration  with  the  Korea  Financial  Telecommunications  and  Clearing  Institute  (KFTC). 
Capacity building activities such as workshops for key NPCI/NIPL staff, joint hackathons among 
NPCI/NIPL  and  Korean  fintech  companies, regional  policy  dialogues  and  meetings  among 
stakeholders,  and  knowledge-sharing  and  awareness-raising  events  will  be  undertaken  to 
prepare NIPL to cater to an advanced market with a larger volume of digital transactions.  
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
15.  The TA is estimated to cost $550,000, of which $500,000 will be financed on a grant basis 
by the Republic of Korea e-Asia and Knowledge Partnership Fund (EAKPF) and administered by 
ADB. The key expenditure items are listed in Appendix 2. The government will provide counterpart 
support in the form of support staff, office accommodation and supplies, and other in-kind 
contributions. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
16.  ADB will administer the TA while Department of Financial Services (DFS)21 will be the 
executing agency. NPCI and NIPL will be the implementing agencies accountable for the outputs. 
ADB will carry out TA administration, supervision, implementation oversight,22 and communication 
with consultants and stakeholders. The implementation arrangements are summarized in the 
table. 
 
 
18 NPCI is in advanced stage of discussions with BC Card for its mutual acceptance & issuance. A memorandum of 
understanding (MOU) has been signed for adoption of unified payments interface (UPI) & RuPay products in Republic 
of Korea. BC Card customers and NPCI customers will be able to pay using their domestic-use-only cards in India 
and Republic of Korea, respectively. Synergistic effects are expected from the utilization of the infrastructures of the 
two companies through the launch of partnership cards, development of new cooperation models, etc. BC Card is 
Republic of Korea's biggest payment processing company and local brand network headquartered in Seoul, Republic 
of Korea. The company provides end-to-end payment services primarily to financial institutions as well as to 
merchants through its subsidiary company, Smartro. 
19 PMJDY is the government’s mission to ensure everyone has a bank account or equivalent platform to store money. 
20 FASTag is an electronic toll collection system being operated by the National Highway Authorities of India that uses 
Radio frequency-based identification (RFID) technology for collecting road toll’s through prepaid accounts. 
21 DFS is the nodal department in Ministry of Finance, Government of India that is responsible for the functioning of 
banks, financial institutions, insurance companies and the national pension system in India. 
22 Integrity Due Diligence (IDD) checks have been conducted and no significant risks have been identified.

Key Activities with Milestones 
 
1.  Fintech market development plans for promoting cross-border digital payments by National 
Payments Corporation of India and NPCI International Payments Limited developed. 
1.1. Identify and touch base with key stakeholders and nodal agencies in the region’s fintech space (Q3 2020). 
1.2. Hold consultation meetings with potential partner countries in the Asia-Pacific region to identify the scope 
of development studies (Q4 2020).  
1.3. Undertake desk review and expert consultations to conduct in-depth analysis on the promotion of 
interregional cashless digital transactions (Q4 2020). 
1.4. Gather relevant data on primary and secondary digital payments market research and analysis and 
conduct review of literature to support the analytical studies (Q1–Q2 2021).   
1.5. Prepare draft fintech partnership agreements with relevant partners are prepared (Q4 2021). 
1.6. Conduct stakeholder consultations to present draft partnership agreements and preliminary findings (Q2 
2022). 
1.7. Finalize the digital payments partnership models by incorporating the comments from stakeholders (Q3 
2022). 
1.8. Conduct in-depth review, research, and recommendations on regional fintech market development and 
needs assessment across identified partner countries (Q4 2022). 
1.9. Initiate stakeholder discussions for formulating feasible fintech models based on research findings and 
recommendations (Q1 2023). 
1.10. Present draft proposal on innovative fintech models to all stakeholders (Q2 2023). 
1.11. Prepare final proposal and launch of fintech based cashless payment models in new regions (Q2 2023). 
 
2.  Institutional capacity of National Payments Corporation of India and NPCI International Payments 
Limited advanced. 
2.1. NPCI-KFTC: Signing of MOU for Technical collaboration (Q4 2020). 
2.2. Design capacity-building strategy/program for NPCI for improved fintech capacity and engagement with 
key stakeholders across countries (Q2 2021). 
2.3. Design strategies for technical partnership in common areas of interest with Korean fintech agencies 
through joint NPCI-KFTC support (Q3 2022). 
2.4. Conduct stakeholder consultations to present draft/preliminary capacity-building strategies/programs (Q4 
2022). 
2.5. Finalize the strategy for technical partnership by incorporating the comments from stakeholders (Q1 
2023). 
2.6. Conduct joint hackathon through participation from NPCI and Korean fintech companies (Q3 2021).
